qas.question: In what year was Labour shown to have a slight lead?
Who were some of the people striking in 1978-1979?
Who did no one expect to call for a general election?
When did the widespread strikes end?
What was called the "summer of discontent"?
What group of people never went on strike?

context: <b4_0>Callaghan<b4_0/> had been widely expected to call a general election in the autumn of <a0_0>1978<a0_0/> when most opinion polls showed Labour to have a narrow lead. However he decided to extend his wage restraint policy for another year hoping that the economy would be in a better shape for a <b5_0>1979<b5_0/> election. But during the winter of 1978–79 there were widespread strikes among <a1_0><b8_0>lorry drivers<b8_0/><a1_0/>, railway workers, car workers and local government and hospital workers <b6_0>in favour of <a2_0>higher pay<a2_0/>-rises<b6_0/> that caused significant disruption to everyday life. <b7_0>These events<b7_0/> came to be dubbed the "<a3_0>Winter of Discontent<a3_0/>".
